sentence: Salesforce.com ( CRM ) will report its third-quarter numbers November 27.
The company will report after the market close with the consensus calling for earnings of $0.50 per share, up from $0.39 during the same period last year.
CRM was recently trading at $123.59 down $37.60 from its 12-month high and $24.91 above its 12-month low.
InvestorsObserver's Stock Score Report gives CRM a 65 long-term technical score and a 46 short-term technical score.
The stock has recent support above $120 and recent resistance below $130.

Of the 30 analysts who cover the stock 26 rate it Strong Buy, 1 rate it Buy, 3 rate it Hold, 0 rate it Sell, and 0 rate it Strong Sell, CRM gets a score of 66 from InvestorsObserver's Stock Score Report.
Like many tech stocks, CRM hit an all time high in September before selling off over the last two months.
The tech sector has been hit particularly hard during the current market correction, and CRM will need to put up a solid quarterly report for the stock to finally find a solid level of support.

Salesforce has a great earnings track record, with the company posting better than expected profits and sales for each of the last ten quarters, and the market expects another strong report this week.
The street has a whisper number of 55 cents vs the consensus 50 cents, which puts additional pressure on the company to post a big earnings beat.
The street will be quick to punish the stock on any signs of weakness, but the stock also has a lot of upside potential given the extent of its recent losses if the report is able to show strength.
I do not see any reason to avoid the stock at this time, but shareholders should have a clear exit strategy in place just in case the numbers fail to impress.
Analysts have a $171.69 average price target on the stock.
If you want a bullish hedged trade on the stock, consider a 1/18/19 95/100 bull-put credit spread for a $0.45 credit.
That's a potential 9.9% return (64.5% annualized*) and the stock would have to fall 19.5% to cause a problem.
If you want to take a bearish stance on the stock at this time, consider an 1/18/19 150/155 bear-call credit spread for a $0.40 credit.
That's a potential 8.7% return (57% annualized*) and the stock would have to rise 21.7% to cause a problem.
